content:
No one is immune in the Kremlin’s in-fighting

A PRIVATE JET carrying a Russian former minister and billionaire lands in a VIP Moscow airport from Italy where he resides in a plush villa. Lured to Moscow for the birthday party of a former colleague and friend, he gets into a limousine, but is quickly apprehended by the FSB, Russia’s secret police. They take him to jail, and charge him with stealing millions of dollars from Russian taxpayers. This was the story spread by Russian news agencies and social media on March 26th as Mikhail Abyzov, a minister until last year, was taken into custody and charged with embezzlement.

According to Mr Abyzov’s lawyers, the reality was somewhat different. The 46-year old businessmen was arrested in his home in the compound of Barvikha near Moscow, which houses many of Russia’s rich and powerful. A video released by investigators showed a sleek, sporty man wearing a baseball cap and two-day stubble being handcuffed and bundled into a van, which apparently drove him around Moscow for much of the night before delivering him to a cell at 4am the next morning. The video showed his belongings being examined before being taken to his cell. This included a copy of “Homo Deus: a Brief History of Tomorrow" by Yuval Noah Harari.

Mr Abyzov is not by any means the first senior Russia official to go down in this way. Alexei Ulyukaev, a former finance minister, who got into conflict with Igor Sechin, Mr Putin’s confidant and energy tsar, is in prison. A number of senior governors are, too. But Mr Abyzov’s arrest has put a large section of Russia’s elite into a state of consternation precisely because his story seems to be applicable to many former and current officials. A pushy businessman who made little distinction between private and state affairs, Mr Abyzov made money in Russia and enjoyed it in the West.

He joined the government of Dmitry Medvedev, the prime minister, in 2012. He was put in charge of “open government”—an initiative to modernise government affairs by transforming them into electronic form. Like much of Mr Medvedev’s modernisation this was largely a show. The post was abolished in 2018, and Mr Abyzov left the government to enjoy the fruits of his labour. A few years ago his lifestyle would have served as a model for other ex-apparatchiks. As long as you remain loyal, don’t get too greedy and don’t pick the wrong fights you will be safe. His arrest has shattered this illusion, demonstrating to the Russian political class that everyone is vulnerable, unless they are personally protected by Vladimir Putin. All must live in fear.

In a country where corruption is omnipresent, the rule of law is selective and property rights are dependent on the will of the Kremlin, any arrest inevitably sparks a flurry of conspiracy theories and interpretations. One theory was that Mr Abyzov’s arrest was a shot against Mr Medvedev, who apparently learned about it only after it happened and quickly distanced himself from it. He said through his spokesman that the charges against Mr Abyzov were not related to his work in the government but stem from business affairs that preceded it. This put a black mark on Anatoly Chubais, the architect of Russia’s privatisation wave in the 1990s. Mr Chubais hired Mr Abyzov in the 2000s to help him reform the electricity monopoly he was in charge of. Mr Abyzov is now accused of setting up an organised criminal group and selling energy assets to a state company for an inflated price of 4bn roubles ($60ml), which would have almost certainly involved approval from other government officials.

Mr Abyzov had also upset some powerful oligarchs. Mikhail Fridman, the billionaire banker who owns Alfa Group, is pursuing him through courts for a large credit repayment; Viktor Vekselberg, another oligarch, is suing him for $500m in a business dispute. Unlike the arrest last month of Michael Calvey, an American businessman who lived and invested in Russia, which sparked collective, though so far useless, support from the Russian business community, few people feel any sympathy for Mr Abyzov who faces a jail sentence of up to 20 years. (Alexei Navalny, an anti-corruption blogger and opposition leader, claimed credit for exposing Mr Abyzov and his villa in one of his investigations broadcast on YouTube.)

But whatever the motive, Mr Abyzov’s arrest fits into a pattern of growing in-fighting and repression among elite groups that has already consumed oligarchs, governors, senators and mayors who had all considered themselves protected in the 2000s. As though to confirm the trend, the day after Mr Abyzov’s arrest, the FSB detained Viktor Ishaev, a powerful former governor of Khabarovsk region in the far east where the Kremlin’s United Russia party suffered a crushing defeat in a local election last autumn.

Each case may be different, but as Kirill Rogov and Nikolai Petrov, Russian political analysts, argue in their recent report on the first year of Mr Putin’s new term as president, “counter-elite economic repressions have become a systemic and crucial element of the political system.” Whereas only three high-ranking officials were prosecuted in the years between 2001 and 2005, the number of cases against senior members of the government and the Duma reached 35 in 2018. Most of these cases are initiated and carried out by the FSB, the successor to the KGB and the central player in Russian politics.

The wave of cinematic arrests—many carried out at night—have prompted comparisons to the purges of the Bolshevik party in the 1930s. The difference, says Ekaterina Schulmann, a political scientist in Moscow, is that unlike Stalin’s campaign, today’s repressions are neither underpinned by an ideology nor accompanied by propaganda. Those who know how Mr Putin operates say he makes decisions on a case-by-case basis, rather than executing a coherent plan.

However, whether the arrests are centrally co-ordinated or not, they are part of a political process which is shaped by the waning popularity of Mr Putin and his consequent need to reaffirm his legitimacy. “Old inter-elite pacts no longer work. It is an open season, bellum omnium contra omnes ,” Ms Schulmann says. It is hardly surprising that in this war of all against all, the FSB, which has the ultimate resource—the ability to put people in jail—is emerging as top dog.

The new purges might be less severe in scale and violence than those of the 1930s, but are driven by the same predatory instincts. As Mr Abyzov ploughs through “Homo Deus” in his cell, he may reflect on how little human nature has changed.

eg2: loved God more than anything else in the world, even when no one else did!
在这个世界上，诺亚对上帝的爱胜于其他一切，甚至没有人比他更爱上帝！
I explored the Roman Empire, Babylon, the times of  and Abraham. Any era you can name, I went there.
我探险了罗马帝国、巴比伦、诺亚和亚伯拉罕时代，任何你能叫得出名称的时期，我都在那里。
All four of these pitfalls are present in the life of  and we can learn from him how to handle these tests.
所有这四个陷阱都在诺亚的生活中出现了，我们可以向他学习，如何面对这些考验。

eg2: Addicted to Notecards:  Nabokov used 5- by 8-inch index cards to compose and order the scenes in his novels.
爱好便笺。 弗拉基米尔纳博科夫经常用5-8英寸的索引卡去撰写和排序小说的场景。
He says the Russian elite is inclined to suddenly take off and land in a place like the Maldives instead of investing in the Vladimir Region near Moscow.
他说：“俄罗斯的精英们总是出人意料地跑到国外，比如马尔代夫，去投资，而不愿意在莫斯科附近的弗拉基米尔地区投资。”
He also reveals that George Bush said in July 2001 that  Putin had "looked a bit scared" when he accused the then Russian president of selling more than conventional weapons to rogue states.
他还揭露乔治·布什于2001年七月说过这样的话：当他（老布什）指责俄罗斯总统向“恶棍国家”出售多于常规的武器时，弗拉基米尔·普京“看起来有点害怕”呀。

ex: adv. 在哪里；在哪一点上；关系；无先行词

n. 场所
pron. 什么地方
网络 地点；何地；何处
vt. 废除，废止；取消，革除
eg2: I asked them not to abolish AmeriCorps, as they had threatened to do.
我要求他们不要取消美国服务队，因为他们曾经威胁过要这么做。
A democratic government isn’t likely to abolish the peace treaty with Israel – even some of the leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood have said they would respect it.
一个民主的政府不大可能废除与以色列的和平条约——甚至穆斯林兄弟会的一些领导人都说过会尊重这个条约。

wp.apparently y: 显然地;一词在句中可放在不同的位置

ex: adv. 显然地；似乎，表面上
eg2: But apparently this is only an illusion.
但显然这只是一个错觉。
The news had  been aimed at stealing the thunder from his visit.
这篇新闻显然是在对他的访问作先声夺人的报道。
But if you were so inclined,  all you have to do work on the railroad.
不过，如果你有这种想法的话，显然你所需要做的就是——去铁路局工作。

ex: adj. 可适用的；可应用的；合适的
eg2: Users of this document should verify the  data for their specific environment.
该文件的用户应该为指定的环境确认可应用的数据。
When running a pattern against a model with this extension, this pattern will show up on a list of applicable patterns for this model.
当针对一个模型运行具有这种扩展名的模式时，这个模式将显示可适用于这个模型的模式的列表。
The service payloads could be encoded in SOAP messages; however these ideas are applicable even when the messages employ other encodings.
服务有效负荷可以被编码进SOAP消息；即使在消息使用其它编码时，这些想法也是可应用的。

wp.apprehend danger: 觉察危险;觉察危险英语

eg2: Police are advised of the need to "rear scan" — look over their shoulder — and warned not to attempt to apprehend suspects while still "engaged with the cycle".
同时，它还向警察们强调了“后视”——就是扭过头从肩膀上看过去——的重要性，并警告他们当还“骑在自行车上时”不要试图逮捕嫌疑犯。
Their concern, and the concern of the society, is that when the police apprehend a suspect, that man or woman is not sent to jail or condemned to die without due process of law.
法院所关心的，也是社会所关心的，是当警察逮捕一名嫌疑人时，那个人不会未经法律正当程序而被监禁或被判处死刑。
In our vigorous effort to prevent attacks or apprehend criminals, we retain a commitment to human rights and fundamental freedoms.
在我们竭力防范攻击或逮捕犯罪份子的同时，我们继续坚持对人权和基本自由的承诺。

那位亿万富翁拒绝为难民们捐款。
In this fictional country there is a  who lives on the fringes of society who, come nightfall, dresses as a bat.
在这个虚幻国度中，有一位生活在社会边缘的亿万富翁，打扮得像只蝙蝠一样出现在傍晚。

eg2: a bundle of rags/papers/firewood
一捆碎布／报纸／木柴

她怀中紧紧地抱着襁褓中的婴儿。
a bundle of ideas
一套想法
a bundle of graphics packages for your PC
一批个人电脑图形软件包
He wasn't exactly a bundle of laughs(= a happy person to be with) last night.
他昨晚有点让人扫兴。
That car must have cost a bundle.
那部车一定价格不菲。
They bundled her into the back of a car.
他们把她塞进了车后座。
He was bundled off to boarding school.
他被匆匆送到了寄宿学校。
We bundled out onto the street.
我们大伙急忙跑到街上。
A further nine applications are bundled with the system.
该系统免费附送九套应用软件。

wp.Cinematic camera: 电影摄机机;电影摄像机;摄机机

ex: adj. 电影的；影片的
eg2: In one of the most famous soggy  endings of all time, Audrey Hepburn, George Peppard and cat enjoy a raindrenched clinch, but in the novella only Fred and the cat are reunited.
在这部电影最著名的落汤鸡式的结尾中，奥黛丽·赫本、乔治·佩帕德和他们的猫在一起享受倾盆大雨，但在小说中只有弗雷德和这只猫重新聚在了一起。
A fragmented, pick’n’mix  culture, represented on this list by highly referential films such as Kill Bill, Moulin Rouge! and Far from Heaven, is increasingly the norm, not the exception.
一个破碎式的，混合型的电影文化，由这个名单中高度指示性的影片所代表，例如《杀死比尔》，《红磨坊》，《陌路天堂》，这正逐步成为规范而非例外。
Come to think of it, I’m not sure what the  equivalent to Jackson Pollack is. I’m not sure there is one.
我想起来了，我不能确定对于杰克逊·波拉克来说，电影的意义是什么，但肯定不止一个。

eg2: Their views coalesced to form a  policy.
他们的各种观点已统一为一致的政策。

它用一致的方法来管理状态并将事件分组。
The members cooperate with each other and the CF to provide coherent access to the database from any member.
这些成员相互合作且与 CF 一同提供对来自任何成员的数据库的一致访问。

a prison compound
监狱场地
a compound adjective, such as fair-skinned
复合形容词，如 fair-skinned
A compound sentence contains two or more clauses.
复合句包含两个或多个从句。
The problems were compounded by severe food shortages.
严重的食物短缺使问题进一步恶化。
The DNA molecule is compounded from many smaller molecules.
脱氧核糖核酸分子是由许多更小的分子组成的。
liquid soaps compounded with disinfectant
用消毒剂混合制成的皂液

ex: n. 知己；密友

wp.Dark Confidant: 黑暗亲信;亲信;乌明疏疑

eg2: I have been their , their friend, their ally.
我是他们的密友、朋友，他们的同盟。
She had chosen me for her  and I learned all about her quarrels with her lover.
她把我当作知己，于是，我便将她和情人之间的争吵了解得一清二楚。
The best thing to do when we are experiencing pessimistic thoughts is to simply talk it over with a friend, , or professional counselor.
最好的方法是当我们经历悲观的想法时，只需要跟朋友，密友或者专业的心里辅导师讲出来就好了。

ex: n. 结果
adj. 随之发生的；作为结果的

wp.consequent shortage: 随之而来的短缺;因而缺少

eg2: This would be good news all round were it not for the consequent crash in banking confidence.
这对所有人来说都是一个好消息，但对于信心业已崩溃的银行业来说并非如此。
If we got an if then statement are we asserting an antecedent, an if clause or the , Q the then clause, or are we saying if P then Q.
如果我们的论述中有如果,我们在主张先行词，假设条件句或者结果，然后从句，或者我们说如果P那么。
She talks frequently about how much she loved them and how much they loved her, how they were highly intelligent but rendered hopeless at parenting by their drug dependence and consequent poverty.
她经常说她很爱她父母，她父母也很爱她，她还说，她父母其实非常聪明，只是由于毒瘾和由此引起的贫困才使他们没有能力教养她们姐妹。

wp.civil conspiracy: 民事共谋;		民事方面的共谋

ex: n. 阴谋；共谋；阴谋集团
eg2: He was implicated in a .
他卷入了一宗阴谋。
We successfully thwarted the enemy's .
我们成功地挫败了敌人的阴谋。
If so, you may be the victim of a subliminal advertising !
如果是这样，你可能就成了阈下广告阴谋的受害者！
